docs.title: 📘 What is UBI?
docs.text:
UBI (Universal Base Image) is the baseline container environment for all Ego Hygiene projects. It provides a reproducible, stable, and developer-experience-optimized foundation that every devcontainer and project in the organization builds upon.

Instead of each project maintaining its own environment setup, UBI serves as the single source of truth — ensuring:

  • Consistency: Every developer works in an identical environment
  • Reproducibility: Builds are deterministic and versioned
  • Developer Happiness: Pre-configured with sensible defaults and modern tooling
  • Maintainability: Update the base once, benefit everywhere

UBI is distributed via GitHub Container Registry (GHCR) and consumed by other repositories as their base image.

docs.title: 🗂️ Fully XDG-Aligned Filesystem
docs.text: Adheres to the XDG Base Directory Specification for predictable configuration and data locations.

docs.title: 📁 /opt/universal/* Hierarchy
docs.text:
Standardized paths for binaries, configs, caches, logs, and more:

  • /opt/universal/bin - Universal binaries
  • /opt/universal/config - Configuration files (XDG_CONFIG_HOME)
  • /opt/universal/cache - Cache directory (XDG_CACHE_HOME)
  • /opt/universal/toolbox - Data files (XDG_DATA_HOME)
  • /opt/universal/runtime - Runtime state (XDG_STATE_HOME)
  • /opt/universal/logs - Centralized logs
  • /opt/universal/apps - Application resources

docs.text: Pre-configured environment variables for consistent behavior across all projects and CI/CD pipelines.

docs.title: Problem Summary
docs.text: The original bump-my-version CHANGELOG rule used a regex pattern that caused duplicate version insertions and corrupted the CHANGELOG structure during automated version bumps.

docs.title: The Problem Patterns
docs.text:
1. Pattern: \A## (Start of string)
  2. Issue: CHANGELOG.md starts with # Changelog\n\n, not ##
  3. Result: Matches 0 times - pattern is ineffective

  4. Impact: No CHANGELOG updates occur

  5. Pattern: ^## (Start of line with MULTILINE)

  6. Issue: Matches every version header in the file
  7. Result: Matches 6+ times for all version sections
  8. Impact: Creates duplicate entries on each bump

docs.title: CHANGELOG Structure
docs.text:
# Changelog

## 0.1.5 (2025-12-11)
[Compare the full difference.](...)

### Changed
- Some changes

## 0.1.4 (2025-12-11)
[Compare the full difference.](...)

docs.title: Correct Pattern: (# Changelog\n\n)##
docs.text:
This pattern:

  • Matches the literal string # Changelog ##
  • Captures # Changelog as group 1
  • Targets only the first occurrence after the header
  • Works regardless of how many version sections exist

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
[[tool.bumpversion.files]]
filename = "CHANGELOG.md"
regex = true
search = "(# Changelog\\n\\n)## "
replace = "\\g<1>## {new_version} ({now:%Y-%m-%d})\n[Compare the full difference.](https://github.com/egohygiene/ubi/compare/{current_version}...{new_version})\n\n## "

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. Search: Finds # Changelog ## at the start
  2. Capture: Group 1 = # Changelog
  3. Replace: Reconstructs with: <captured header> + <new version> + ##
  4. Result: New version inserted between header and first existing version

docs.title: Test Results
docs.text: ✅ Single bump: Adds exactly 1 new section ✅ Multiple bumps: No duplication across sequential versions ✅ Structure: Preserves CHANGELOG format ✅ Position: New version appears at top (after header)

docs.title: Dry-Run Output
docs.text:
$ bump-my-version bump patch --dry-run

File CHANGELOG.md: replace `(# Changelog\n\n)## ` with ...
  Found '(# Changelog\n\n)## ' at line 1: # Changelog

##
  Would change file CHANGELOG.md:
    *** before CHANGELOG.md
    --- after CHANGELOG.md
    ***************
    *** 1,4 ****
    --- 1,7 ----
      # Changelog
    +
    + ## 0.1.6 (2025-12-13)
    + [Compare the full difference.](https://github.com/egohygiene/ubi/compare/0.1.5...0.1.6)

      ## 0.1.5 (2025-12-11)
      [Compare the full difference.](https://github.com/egohygiene/ubi/compare/0.1.4...0.1.5)

docs.title: Verification Steps
docs.text:
To verify the fix works correctly:

# 1. Dry-run bump to see what would change
bump-my-version bump patch --dry-run --verbose

# 2. Check that only ONE occurrence is matched
# Look for: "Found '(# Changelog\n\n)## ' at line 1"

# 3. Verify the diff shows exactly one new section
# The diff should show: +3 lines (header + link + blank)

# 4. Confirm no duplication in subsequent bumps
# Run multiple dry-runs and verify each adds only 1 section

docs.title: Regex Anchors Comparison
docs.text: Anchor Meaning Effect on CHANGELOG \A Start of string Doesn't match (file starts with # Changelog) ^ Start of line Matches ALL version headers (with MULTILINE) (# Changelog\n\n) Literal match Matches only the header + first version

docs.title: Capture Groups
docs.text:
• Group 0: Full match # Changelog ##
  • Group 1: Captured # Changelog
  • \g<1>: Backreference to restore the captured header

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: UBI (Universal Base Image) serves as the foundational development container for all Ego Hygiene projects. It provides a consistent, reproducible, and developer-experience-optimized platform that eliminates environment drift and configuration overhead.

docs.title: 1. Consistency Across Projects
docs.text:
Every developer and CI environment works with an identical baseline, ensuring:

  • Predictable behavior across local development and CI/CD
  • Reduced "works on my machine" issues
  • Standardized tooling and configuration

docs.title: 2. Reproducibility
docs.text:
All builds are deterministic and auditable through:

  • Semantic versioning (SemVer)
  • Pinned base image with digest verification
  • Version-tagged releases published to GHCR
  • Immutable container images

docs.title: 3. Developer Experience (DX)
docs.text:
Sensible defaults reduce friction:

  • Pre-configured environment variables
  • Standardized filesystem layout
  • XDG-compliant directory structure
  • Telemetry disabled by default
  • Modern terminal and editor support

docs.title: 4. Maintainability
docs.text:
Single source of truth for environment configuration:

  • Update once, benefit everywhere
  • Clear versioning and changelog
  • Automated release pipeline
  • Security scanning and SBOM generation

docs.title: XDG Base Directory Strategy
docs.text: UBI follows the XDG Base Directory Specification to provide predictable locations for configuration, cache, and application data.

docs.title: Standard XDG Variables
docs.text:
XDG_CONFIG_HOME=/opt/universal/config   # Application configuration
XDG_CACHE_HOME=/opt/universal/cache     # Application caches
XDG_DATA_HOME=/opt/universal/toolbox    # Application data
XDG_STATE_HOME=/opt/universal/runtime   # Application state

docs.title: Benefits
docs.text:
• Predictability: Applications know where to store data
  • Cleanliness: No scattered dotfiles in home directory
  • Isolation: Clear separation between config, cache, and data
  • Compliance: Industry-standard approach adopted by modern tools

docs.title: Universal Filesystem Layout
docs.text: The /opt/universal hierarchy provides a centralized, organized structure for all development resources.

docs.title: Directory Structure
docs.text:
/opt/universal/
├── bin/           # Universal binaries and executables
├── config/        # Configuration files (XDG_CONFIG_HOME)
├── cache/         # Cache directory (XDG_CACHE_HOME)
│   └── apt/       # APT package cache
├── toolbox/       # Data files (XDG_DATA_HOME)
├── runtime/       # Runtime state (XDG_STATE_HOME)
├── logs/          # Centralized application logs
├── apps/          # Application resources (XDG_DATA_DIRS)
├── reports/       # Generated reports and artifacts
├── lib/           # Shared libraries
├── locks/         # Lock files for resource coordination
└── fonts/         # Custom fonts

docs.text:

docs.title: Devcontainer Architecture
docs.text: UBI is designed to be consumed as a base image for VS Code devcontainers.

docs.title: Usage Pattern
docs.text:
Projects inherit from UBI and extend as needed:

{
  "name": "My Project",
  "image": "ghcr.io/egohygiene/ubi:0.1.5",
  "features": {
    // Project-specific devcontainer features
  },
  "customizations": {
    "vscode": {
      // VS Code settings
    }
  }
}

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Base Image: mcr.microsoft.com/devcontainers/base:2.1.2 (pinned with digest)
  • User: vscode (non-root by default)
  • Shell: Bash with safer defaults (errexit, pipefail, nounset)
  • Security: No privileged mode required (see security documentation)

docs.title: Build Pipeline
docs.text:
UBI uses a fully automated CI/CD pipeline powered by GitHub Actions.

graph LR
    A[Version Bump] --> B[Git Tag]
    B --> C[Trigger Publish]
    C --> D[Build Image]
    D --> E[Security Scan]
    E --> F[Generate SBOM]
    F --> G[Push to GHCR]

docs.title: Workflows
docs.text:
1. bump-version.yml: Manual trigger to bump SemVer version
  2. Uses bump-my-version tool
  3. Updates VERSION, CHANGELOG.md, and pyproject.toml

  4. Creates git commit and tag

  5. publish.yml: Automated image build and publish

  6. Triggered on push to main or tag creation
  7. Multi-platform builds (amd64, arm64)
  8. Publishes to GHCR with multiple tags

  9. Generates SBOM with Syft

  10. trivy-scan.yml: Container vulnerability scanning

  11. Runs on PRs, pushes, and weekly schedule
  12. Scans for CVEs in base image and dependencies

  13. Uploads results to GitHub Security tab

  14. test-image.yml: Image validation

  15. Tests container functionality
  16. Validates environment variables
  17. Checks directory structure

docs.title: Multi-Stage Build Process
docs.text: The Dockerfile uses a three-stage build for clarity and organization.

docs.title: Stage 1: Base
docs.text:
FROM mcr.microsoft.com/devcontainers/base:2.1.2@sha256:... AS base
  • Establishes the foundation from Microsoft's devcontainer base
  • Sets safer shell defaults
  • Pinned with digest for reproducibility

docs.title: Stage 2: Environment
docs.text:
FROM base AS environment
  • Defines all build arguments (ARGs)
  • Sets environment variables (ENVs)
  • Configures XDG directories
  • Establishes the /opt/universal structure

docs.title: Stage 3: Final
docs.text:
FROM environment AS final
  • Creates universal directories with proper permissions
  • Sets up the vscode user
  • Configures PATH and shell environment
  • Final image ready for consumption

docs.title: Build Arguments
docs.text:
UBI supports customization via build arguments:

docker build \
  --build-arg LANG=en_US.UTF-8 \
  --build-arg TZ=America/New_York \
  --build-arg EDITOR=vim \
  -f .devcontainer/Dockerfile \
  -t ubi:custom .

docs.title: Semantic Versioning (SemVer)
docs.text:
UBI follows strict SemVer: MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH

  • MAJOR: Breaking changes to environment or filesystem structure
  • MINOR: New features, tools, or non-breaking enhancements
  • PATCH: Bug fixes and minor updates

docs.title: Version Sources
docs.text:
• VERSION file: Single source of truth (e.g., 0.1.5)
  • pyproject.toml: Python tooling compatibility
  • CHANGELOG.md: Automatically updated on version bump
  • Git tags: Created automatically by bump workflow

docs.title: Image Tags
docs.text:
Every release publishes multiple tags to GHCR:

ghcr.io/egohygiene/ubi:latest          # Always points to latest stable
ghcr.io/egohygiene/ubi:0.1.5           # Specific version (pinned)
ghcr.io/egohygiene/ubi:sha-abc123      # Git commit SHA (reproducibility)

Recommendation: Use specific version tags (e.g., 0.1.5) in production environments.

docs.title: Security Architecture
docs.text:
UBI implements multiple layers of security:

  1. Base Image Pinning: Digest-pinned base image prevents supply chain attacks
  2. No Privileged Mode: Container runs with standard isolation (see privileged-mode.md)
  3. Vulnerability Scanning: Automated Trivy scans on every build
  4. SBOM Generation: Software Bill of Materials for transparency
  5. Non-Root User: Runs as vscode user by default

For detailed security information, see security-overview.md.

  • Centralized: Single hierarchy for all resources
  • Predictable: Clear structure easy to navigate and understand
  • Non-Intrusive: Doesn't conflict with system directories

docs.title: Why Pin Base Image with Digest?
docs.text:
• Reproducibility: Same digest always pulls identical image
  • Security: Prevents tag hijacking and supply chain attacks
  • Auditability: Exact image version is traceable
  • Stability: Protects against unexpected upstream changes

docs.title: Why Semantic Versioning?
docs.text:
• Clarity: Clear communication of change impact
  • Automation: Tools can parse and compare versions
  • Standard: Industry-wide convention
  • Predictability: Consumers know what to expect

  • Base remains stable and minimal
  • Extensions don't affect UBI's core functionality

docs.title: Using UBI as a Dockerfile Base
docs.text:
You can also extend UBI in your own Dockerfile:

Dockerfile
FROM ghcr.io/egohygiene/ubi:0.1.5

# Install project-specific dependencies
RUN apt-get update && apt-get install -y \
    nodejs \
    npm \
    && rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/*

# Set working directory
WORKDIR /workspace

# Copy project files
COPY . .

# Install dependencies
RUN npm install

docs.title: Multi-Stage Build with UBI
docs.text:
Use UBI as a build environment and create a minimal runtime image:

Dockerfile
# Build stage using UBI
FROM ghcr.io/egohygiene/ubi:0.1.5 AS builder

WORKDIR /build
COPY . .
RUN make build

# Runtime stage
FROM debian:bookworm-slim

# Copy artifacts from builder
COPY --from=builder /build/dist /app

ENTRYPOINT ["/app/myapp"]

docs.text:
Leverage UBI's XDG-compliant directory structure:

example-script.sh
#!/bin/bash

# Use XDG environment variables
CONFIG_FILE="${XDG_CONFIG_HOME}/myapp/config.yml"
CACHE_DIR="${XDG_CACHE_HOME}/myapp"
DATA_DIR="${XDG_DATA_HOME}/myapp"

# Create directories if they don't exist
mkdir -p "$(dirname "$CONFIG_FILE")"
mkdir -p "$CACHE_DIR"
mkdir -p "$DATA_DIR"

# Write configuration
cat > "$CONFIG_FILE" <<EOF
app:
  name: MyApp
  cache_dir: $CACHE_DIR
  data_dir: $DATA_DIR
EOF

docs.text:
Add your own environment variables while preserving UBI's defaults:

  "name": "My Project",
  "image": "ghcr.io/egohygiene/ubi:latest",
  "containerEnv": {
    "MY_APP_ENV": "development",
    "MY_APP_DEBUG": "true"

docs.text:
Dockerfile
FROM ghcr.io/egohygiene/ubi:0.1.5

# Install Python dependencies
COPY requirements.txt .
RUN pip install --no-cache-dir -r requirements.txt

# Set Python path to use XDG directories
ENV PYTHONUSERBASE="${XDG_DATA_HOME}/python"
ENV PATH="${PYTHONUSERBASE}/bin:${PATH}"

WORKDIR /workspace
COPY . .

docs.title: Node.js Project
docs.text:
Dockerfile
FROM ghcr.io/egohygiene/ubi:0.1.5

# Install Node.js
RUN curl -fsSL https://deb.nodesource.com/setup_20.x | bash - \
    && apt-get install -y nodejs \
    && rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/*

# Configure npm to use XDG directories
ENV NPM_CONFIG_USERCONFIG="${XDG_CONFIG_HOME}/npm/npmrc"
ENV NPM_CONFIG_CACHE="${XDG_CACHE_HOME}/npm"
ENV NPM_CONFIG_PREFIX="${XDG_DATA_HOME}/npm"

WORKDIR /workspace
COPY package*.json ./
RUN npm install

COPY . .

docs.title: Go Project
docs.text:
Dockerfile
FROM ghcr.io/egohygiene/ubi:0.1.5

# Install Go
ARG GO_VERSION=1.22.0
RUN wget -q https://go.dev/dl/go${GO_VERSION}.linux-amd64.tar.gz \
    && tar -C /usr/local -xzf go${GO_VERSION}.linux-amd64.tar.gz \
    && rm go${GO_VERSION}.linux-amd64.tar.gz

# Configure Go to use XDG directories
ENV GOPATH="${XDG_DATA_HOME}/go"
ENV GOCACHE="${XDG_CACHE_HOME}/go-build"
ENV PATH="/usr/local/go/bin:${GOPATH}/bin:${PATH}"

WORKDIR /workspace
COPY go.* ./
RUN go mod download

COPY . .
RUN go build -o /app/myapp

docs.title: Release Process
docs.text: This document describes the complete release process for UBI, from version bumping to publishing the container image to GitHub Container Registry (GHCR).

docs.title: Table of Contents
docs.text:
• Overview
  • VERSION File Rules
  • Semantic Versioning
  • Version Bump Workflow
  • Publish Pipeline
  • GitHub Release Creation
  • SBOM Generation
  • Release Checklist
  • Troubleshooting

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
UBI uses a fully automated release pipeline that follows this flow:

graph TD
    A[Manual: Trigger Version Bump] --> B[bump-my-version updates files]
    B --> C[Commit with version changes]
    C --> D[Create Git Tag]
    D --> E[Push to GitHub]
    E --> F[Auto-trigger Publish Workflow]
    E --> K[Auto-trigger Release Notes Workflow]
    F --> G[Build Multi-Platform Image]
    G --> H[Generate SBOM]
    H --> I[Push to GHCR]
    I --> J[Tag: latest, version, sha-XXX]
    K --> L[Extract CHANGELOG section]
    L --> M[Wait for Publish to complete]
    M --> N[Create GitHub Release with SBOM]

Key Principles:

  • Single source of truth: VERSION file
  • Automated synchronization across files
  • Git tags trigger image publishing
  • Semantic versioning (SemVer) enforced

docs.title: VERSION File Rules
docs.text: The VERSION file at the repository root is the single source of truth for the current version.

docs.title: Format
docs.text:
0.1.5

Rules:

  • Plain text file, no comments
  • Single line with semantic version number
  • Format: MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH (e.g., 0.1.5)
  • Trailing newline (Unix line ending: LF)
  • No whitespace except trailing newline
  • No prefixes (no v prefix)

docs.title: Valid Examples
docs.text:
# ✅ Valid
0.1.5

1.0.0

2.3.1

docs.title: Invalid Examples
docs.text:
# ❌ Invalid
v0.1.5          # No prefix allowed
0.1.5-beta      # No pre-release tags
 0.1.5          # No leading whitespace
0.1.5 \n\n      # Only one trailing newline

docs.title: Checking VERSION File
docs.text:
# View content with visible whitespace
cat -A VERSION

# Should output ($ represents newline):
# 0.1.5$

# Verify format
if [[ $(cat VERSION) =~ ^[0-9]+\.[0-9]+\.[0-9]+$ ]]; then
  echo "✅ Valid"
else
  echo "❌ Invalid format"
fi

docs.title: Semantic Versioning
docs.text: UBI follows Semantic Versioning 2.0.0.

docs.title: Version Format
docs.text:
MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH

Note: Pre-release versions (e.g., 1.0.0-alpha, 2.0.0-beta.1) are not supported based on the VERSION file format rules. Only stable release versions are allowed.

docs.title: MAJOR version (X.0.0)
docs.text:
Increment for breaking changes that require consumers to modify their setup:

  • Changes to /opt/universal directory structure
  • Removal or renaming of environment variables
  • Changes to base image that break compatibility
  • Removal of previously supported features

Example: Moving from /opt/universal/bin to /opt/ubi/bin → 1.0.0

docs.title: MINOR version (0.X.0)
docs.text:
Increment for new features that are backwards-compatible:

  • Addition of new environment variables
  • Addition of new directories in /opt/universal
  • New tools or utilities installed
  • Non-breaking enhancements to existing features

Example: Adding new telemetry opt-outs → 0.2.0

docs.title: PATCH version (0.0.X)
docs.text:
Increment for bug fixes and minor updates:

  • Security patches to base image
  • Bug fixes that don't change functionality
  • Documentation updates
  • Internal refactoring without external impact
  • Dependency updates (if no behavior change)

Example: Fixing a typo in environment variable → 0.0.6

docs.title: Special Cases
docs.text:
• Pre-1.0.0: Breaking changes are allowed in MINOR versions
  • 0.1.0 → 0.2.0 can include breaking changes

  • After 1.0.0, breaking changes require MAJOR bump

  • Security Fixes:

  • If critical, may warrant out-of-band patch release
  • Document clearly in CHANGELOG

docs.title: Version Bump Workflow
docs.text: Version bumping is handled by the bump-version.yml GitHub Actions workflow.

docs.title: Triggering a Version Bump
docs.text:
1. Navigate to Actions tab in GitHub:
  2. Go to: https://github.com/egohygiene/ubi/actions

  3. Select "🔼 Bump UBI Version" workflow

  4. Click "Run workflow"

  5. Select bump type:

  6. major - For breaking changes (X.0.0)
  7. minor - For new features (0.X.0)

  8. patch - For bug fixes (0.0.X)

  9. Click "Run workflow" button

docs.title: What Happens Automatically
docs.text:
The workflow performs these steps:

  1. Checkout repository with full git history

  2. Install bump-my-version:

pip install bump-my-version
  1. Bump version using configuration in pyproject.toml:
bump-my-version [major|minor|patch]
  1. Files updated automatically:
  2. VERSION - Updated to new version
  3. pyproject.toml - Updated in two places:
    • [tool.poetry] version
    • [tool.bumpversion] current_version

  4. CHANGELOG.md - New version section inserted at top

  5. Create commit:

chore: bump version to X.Y.Z
  1. Create git tag:
X.Y.Z
  1. Push commit and tag to main branch

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
Version bump behavior is configured in pyproject.toml:

[tool.bumpversion]
current_version = "0.1.5"
parse = "^(?P<major>\\d+)\\.(?P<minor>\\d+)\\.(?P<patch>\\d+)$"
serialize = ["{major}.{minor}.{patch}"]
commit = true
message = "chore: bump version to {new_version}"
tag = false  # Tagging done by CI

[[tool.bumpversion.files]]
filename = "VERSION"
search = "{current_version}"
replace = "{new_version}"

[[tool.bumpversion.files]]
filename = "CHANGELOG.md"
regex = true
search = "\\A## "
replace = """## {new_version} ({now:%Y-%m-%d})
[Compare the full difference.](https://github.com/egohygiene/ubi/compare/{current_version}...{new_version})

## """

docs.title: Local Version Bump (Testing)
docs.text:
To test version bumps locally without pushing:

# Install tool
pip install bump-my-version

# Dry run (no changes)
bump-my-version patch --dry-run --verbose

# Actually bump (creates commit, no tag)
bump-my-version patch

# Undo if needed
git reset --hard HEAD~1

docs.title: Publish Pipeline
docs.text: The publish.yml workflow builds and publishes the UBI image to GHCR.

docs.title: Triggers
docs.text:
The publish workflow runs automatically on:

  • Push to main branch (after version bump commit)
  • Tag creation (after version bump workflow)
  • Manual trigger (workflow_dispatch)

docs.title: Build Process
docs.text:
1. Checkout repository

  2. Read VERSION file:

VERSION=$(cat VERSION | tr -d '[:space:]')
  1. Set up build environment:
  2. QEMU for multi-architecture support

  3. Docker Buildx for multi-platform builds

  4. Authenticate to GHCR:

echo $GITHUB_TOKEN | docker login ghcr.io -u ${{ github.repository_owner }} --password-stdin
  1. Generate metadata (tags and labels):
tags: |
  type=raw,value=latest
  type=raw,value=${{ VERSION }}
  type=sha
  1. Build multi-platform image:
  2. Platforms: linux/amd64, linux/arm64
  3. Context: Repository root

  4. Dockerfile: .devcontainer/Dockerfile

  5. Push to GHCR with multiple tags:

ghcr.io/egohygiene/ubi:latest
ghcr.io/egohygiene/ubi:0.1.5
ghcr.io/egohygiene/ubi:sha-abc123

docs.title: Published Tags
docs.text:
Every release creates three tags:

Tag Format Example Purpose latest ghcr.io/egohygiene/ubi:latest Always points to newest stable release X.Y.Z ghcr.io/egohygiene/ubi:0.1.5 Pinned version for reproducibility sha-XXXXXX ghcr.io/egohygiene/ubi:sha-abc123 Git commit SHA for exact reproducibility

docs.title: Recommendations
docs.text:
• Production: Use specific version tags (0.1.5)
  • Development: Use latest for convenience
  • Maximum reproducibility: Use sha-XXXXXX tags

docs.title: GitHub Release Creation
docs.text: The release-notes.yml workflow automatically creates GitHub Releases with release notes.

docs.title: Triggers
docs.text:
The release notes workflow runs automatically on:

  • Tag creation (when version bump workflow creates a tag)

docs.title: Release Creation Process
docs.text:
1. Checkout repository at the tagged version

  2. Extract version from tag:

TAG_NAME="${GITHUB_REF#refs/tags/}"
VERSION="${TAG_NAME#v}"  # Remove 'v' prefix if present
  1. Extract changelog section for this version:

Uses awk to extract the section between ## VERSION headers in CHANGELOG.md

  1. Wait for publish workflow to complete:

Ensures the container image and SBOM are available before creating the release

  1. Download SBOM artifact:

Fetches the SBOM generated by the publish workflow (ubi-sbom-X.Y.Z)

  1. Create GitHub Release:

  2. Title: Version number (e.g., 0.1.5)

  3. Body: Extracted changelog section
  4. Assets: SBOM file (if available)
  5. Additional info: Container image pull instructions, tags, and links

docs.title: Release Contents
docs.text:
Each GitHub Release includes:

  • Release Notes: Extracted from CHANGELOG.md
  • SBOM Attachment: Software Bill of Materials in SPDX-JSON format
  • Container Image Info: Pull instructions for all tags
  • Links:
  • Compare changes
  • Full CHANGELOG.md
  • Documentation

docs.title: Accessing Releases
docs.text:
1. GitHub Releases Page:
  2. Visit: https://github.com/egohygiene/ubi/releases
  3. View all releases and their notes

  4. Download SBOM attachments

  5. Latest Release:

  6. Direct link: https://github.com/egohygiene/ubi/releases/latest

  7. Specific Version:

  8. Format: https://github.com/egohygiene/ubi/releases/tag/X.Y.Z
  9. Example: https://github.com/egohygiene/ubi/releases/tag/0.1.5

docs.title: SBOM Generation
docs.text: A Software Bill of Materials (SBOM) is generated for every published image.

docs.title: What is an SBOM?
docs.text:
An SBOM is a formal, machine-readable inventory of:

  • All software components in the image
  • Package names and versions
  • Dependencies and relationships
  • License information
  • Security vulnerability data

docs.title: Generation Process
docs.text:
The publish workflow uses Syft to generate SBOMs:

- name: Generate SBOM
  uses: anchore/sbom-action@v0
  with:
    image: ghcr.io/egohygiene/ubi:${{ VERSION }}
    format: spdx-json
    output-file: ubi-sbom.spdx.json

docs.title: SBOM Format
docs.text:
• Format: SPDX-JSON (Software Package Data Exchange)
  • Standard: SPDX 2.3
  • Output: ubi-sbom.spdx.json

docs.title: Accessing SBOMs
docs.text:
1. Workflow Artifacts:
  2. Navigate to workflow run: https://github.com/egohygiene/ubi/actions/workflows/publish.yml
  3. Download artifact: ubi-sbom-X.Y.Z

  4. Retention: 90 days

  5. Generate Locally:

# Install Syft
brew install syft  # macOS
# or
curl -sSfL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/anchore/syft/main/install.sh | sh -s -- -b /usr/local/bin

# Generate SBOM
syft ghcr.io/egohygiene/ubi:0.1.5 -o spdx-json > ubi-sbom.json

docs.title: SBOM Use Cases
docs.text:
• Supply chain security: Track all components
  • Vulnerability management: Cross-reference with CVE databases
  • Compliance: Meet regulatory requirements
  • Auditing: Verify what's in production images
  • License compliance: Identify OSS licenses

docs.title: Release Checklist
docs.text: Use this checklist when preparing a release:

docs.title: Pre-Release
docs.text:
• All changes merged to main branch
  • CI/CD workflows passing (build, test, security scan)
  • Documentation updated (if applicable)
  • CHANGELOG manually updated with release notes (optional, bump-my-version adds header)
  • Tested image locally

docs.title: Release
docs.text:
• Determine bump type (major/minor/patch)
  • Trigger "🔼 Bump UBI Version" workflow with correct type
  • Verify workflow completes successfully
  • Confirm commit and tag created in repository
  • Wait for "🚀 Publish UBI Image" workflow to trigger
  • Verify publish workflow completes successfully
  • Wait for "📝 Create GitHub Release" workflow to trigger
  • Verify GitHub Release is created with correct notes and SBOM

docs.title: Post-Release
docs.text:
• Verify image available on GHCR:
docker pull ghcr.io/egohygiene/ubi:latest
docker pull ghcr.io/egohygiene/ubi:X.Y.Z
  • Test pulled image:
docker run -it --rm ghcr.io/egohygiene/ubi:X.Y.Z bash
  • Verify SBOM artifact uploaded
  • Check GitHub Release page for release notes and SBOM attachment
  • Update dependent projects (if needed)
  • Announce release (if significant)

docs.title: Version Bump Fails
docs.text:
Problem: Workflow fails at bump step

Solutions:

  1. Check pyproject.toml configuration matches VERSION file
  2. Verify VERSION file format is correct
  3. Review workflow logs for specific error
  4. See Troubleshooting Guide

docs.title: Publish Fails to Push Image
docs.text:
Problem: Image builds but doesn't push to GHCR

Solutions:

  1. Verify workflow has packages: write permission
  2. Check GHCR authentication
  3. Confirm image size is within limits
  4. Review Docker Buildx logs

docs.title: Tag Already Exists
docs.text:
Problem: Cannot create tag because it already exists

Solutions:

  1. Verify you're bumping the correct version component
  2. Delete tag if needed:
git tag -d X.Y.Z
git push origin :refs/tags/X.Y.Z
  1. Re-run bump workflow

docs.title: SBOM Generation Fails
docs.text:
Problem: SBOM step fails in publish workflow

Solutions:

  1. Check if image was successfully built
  2. Verify Syft action version
  3. Review Syft logs for specific errors
  4. Try generating SBOM manually (see above)

docs.title: GitHub Release Not Created
docs.text:
Problem: Tag is pushed but GitHub Release is not created

Solutions:

  1. Check if "📝 Create GitHub Release" workflow was triggered
  2. Review workflow logs in Actions tab
  3. Verify CHANGELOG.md has an entry for this version
  4. Check if publish workflow completed successfully (release workflow waits for it)
  5. Manually create release if needed:
  6. Go to https://github.com/egohygiene/ubi/releases/new
  7. Select the tag
  8. Copy content from CHANGELOG.md
  9. Attach SBOM from workflow artifacts

docs.title: Release Missing SBOM
docs.text:
Problem: GitHub Release created but SBOM is not attached

Solutions:

  1. Check if publish workflow completed successfully
  2. Verify SBOM artifact was uploaded in publish workflow
  3. Check release-notes workflow logs for artifact download step
  4. Download SBOM from publish workflow artifacts and manually attach to release

docs.title: Manual Release (Emergency)
docs.text: In case automated workflows fail, you can perform a manual release:

docs.title: 1. Manual Version Bump
docs.text:
# Update VERSION file
echo "0.1.6" > VERSION

# Update pyproject.toml manually
# Edit [tool.poetry] version and [tool.bumpversion] current_version

# Update CHANGELOG.md (add new section at top)

# Commit
git add VERSION pyproject.toml CHANGELOG.md
git commit -m "chore: bump version to 0.1.6"

# Tag
git tag 0.1.6

# Push
git push origin main
git push origin 0.1.6

docs.title: 2. Manual Image Build and Push
docs.text:
# Read version
VERSION=$(cat VERSION | tr -d '[:space:]')

# Login to GHCR
echo $GITHUB_TOKEN | docker login ghcr.io -u USERNAME --password-stdin

# Build multi-platform
docker buildx build \
  --platform linux/amd64,linux/arm64 \
  --file .devcontainer/Dockerfile \
  --tag ghcr.io/egohygiene/ubi:latest \
  --tag ghcr.io/egohygiene/ubi:$VERSION \
  --push \
  .

docs.title: 3. Manual SBOM Generation
docs.text: syft ghcr.io/egohygiene/ubi:$VERSION -o spdx-json > ubi-sbom.json

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Always use the workflow for releases (avoid manual steps)
  2. Test locally first before bumping version
  3. Write clear CHANGELOG entries explaining changes
  4. Follow SemVer strictly for predictability
  5. Verify images work before announcing releases
  6. Keep VERSION file clean (no extra whitespace)
  7. Document breaking changes prominently in CHANGELOG
  8. Use specific tags in production, not latest

docs.text: This document provides an overview of UBI's security practices, threat model, and security-related configurations.

docs.title: Table of Contents
docs.text:

docs.title: Security Philosophy
docs.text:
UBI follows a defense-in-depth approach with multiple layers of security:

  1. Principle of Least Privilege: Run with minimal necessary permissions
  2. Transparency: SBOM generation for full supply chain visibility
  3. Proactive Scanning: Automated vulnerability detection
  4. Reproducibility: Pinned dependencies prevent supply chain attacks
  5. Regular Updates: Keep base image and dependencies current

Key Principle: Security is a continuous process, not a one-time configuration.

docs.title: Assets to Protect
docs.text:
• Host System: The machine running the container
  • Container Runtime: Docker daemon and orchestration layer
  • Source Code: Developer's projects in /workspace
  • Credentials: Git tokens, API keys, SSH keys
  • Build Artifacts: Compiled code and dependencies

docs.title: Threats Considered

  • Follows best practice for development containers

docs.title: Vulnerability Scanning

docs.title: What Trivy Scans

docs.title: When Scanning Occurs

docs.title: Severity Levels
docs.text:
Trivy categorizes vulnerabilities by severity:

Severity Action Build Impact CRITICAL Fix immediately ❌ Fails build HIGH Fix within 30 days ❌ Fails build MEDIUM Fix within 90 days ⚠️ Warning only LOW Fix when convenient ℹ️ Informational NEGLIGIBLE No action needed ℹ️ Informational

docs.title: Running Trivy Locally
docs.text:
# Install Trivy
brew install trivy  # macOS
# or
wget -qO - https://aquasecurity.github.io/trivy-repo/deb/public.key | sudo apt-key add -
echo "deb https://aquasecurity.github.io/trivy-repo/deb $(lsb_release -sc) main" | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/trivy.list
sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get install trivy

# Scan UBI image
trivy image --severity CRITICAL,HIGH ghcr.io/egohygiene/ubi:latest

# Generate report
trivy image --format json --output trivy-report.json ghcr.io/egohygiene/ubi:latest

docs.title: Addressing Vulnerabilities
docs.text:
When Trivy detects vulnerabilities:

  1. Assess Impact:
  2. Is the vulnerable package actually used in UBI?
  3. Is there an exploit available?

  4. What's the attack vector?

  5. Determine Remediation:

  6. Update base image: Check if newer version has fix
  7. Update packages: apt-get upgrade specific packages
  8. Remove package: If not needed, remove it

  9. Accept risk: Document why and track for future fix

  10. Verify Fix:

# Rebuild and rescan
docker build -f .devcontainer/Dockerfile -t ubi:test .
trivy image --severity CRITICAL,HIGH ubi:test
  1. Document:
  2. Update CHANGELOG.md with security fixes
  3. Bump version appropriately (PATCH for security fixes)
  4. Reference CVE IDs in commit messages

docs.title: Supply Chain Security
docs.text: UBI implements multiple supply chain security measures:

docs.title: 1. Base Image Pinning
docs.text:
The base image is pinned with a cryptographic digest:

FROM mcr.microsoft.com/devcontainers/base:2.1.2@sha256:36751f1ee2f30745a649afc2b2061f321bacdaa0617159901fe6725b34c93df4

Benefits:

  • ✅ Immutable - same digest always pulls identical image
  • ✅ Tamper-proof - digest changes if image modified
  • ✅ Reproducible - builds are deterministic
  • ✅ Auditable - exact version is traceable

Risks Mitigated:

  • Tag hijacking (someone overwrites :2.1.2 tag)
  • Man-in-the-middle attacks during pull
  • Accidental upstream changes

docs.title: 2. Dependency Tracking
docs.text:
All dependencies are tracked via:

  • SBOM generation (Syft)
  • Vulnerability scanning (Trivy)
  • Version pinning in Dockerfile (where applicable)

docs.title: 3. Secure Build Pipeline
docs.text:
GitHub Actions workflows use:

  • Pinned action versions (e.g., actions/checkout@v4)
  • Minimal permissions (principle of least privilege)
  • Secrets management via GitHub Secrets
  • Isolated build environments

docs.title: 4. Reproducible Builds
docs.text:
Every build is reproducible via:

  • Git commit SHA tags (sha-abc123)
  • Pinned base image digest
  • Locked dependency versions
  • Documented build process

docs.title: 5. Image Signing with Cosign
docs.text:
Status: ✅ Implemented

UBI images are cryptographically signed using Sigstore Cosign with keyless signing:

# Verify signed image
cosign verify \
  --certificate-identity-regexp="https://github.com/egohygiene/ubi/" \
  --certificate-oidc-issuer="https://token.actions.githubusercontent.com" \
  ghcr.io/egohygiene/ubi:latest

Benefits:

  • ✅ Cryptographic proof of authenticity
  • ✅ Verification of image provenance
  • ✅ Protection against supply chain attacks
  • ✅ Keyless signing via GitHub OIDC (no key management)
  • ✅ Transparency log backed by Sigstore Rekor
  • ✅ Traceable to specific GitHub workflow runs

How It Works:

  1. GitHub Actions workflow builds and pushes the image
  2. Cosign signs the image digest using GitHub OIDC identity
  3. Signature is stored in the container registry alongside the image
  4. Signature is recorded in Sigstore's public transparency log
  5. Anyone can verify the signature without needing access to private keys

What Gets Signed:

  • All published tags (latest, version tags, SHA tags)
  • Signed by digest, so signature covers all architectures (amd64, arm64)
  • Signature metadata includes workflow identity and build context

Verification Example:

# Install Cosign
brew install cosign  # macOS
# or download from https://github.com/sigstore/cosign/releases

# Verify latest image
cosign verify \
  --certificate-identity-regexp="https://github.com/egohygiene/ubi/" \
  --certificate-oidc-issuer="https://token.actions.githubusercontent.com" \
  ghcr.io/egohygiene/ubi:latest

# Verify specific version
cosign verify \
  --certificate-identity-regexp="https://github.com/egohygiene/ubi/" \
  --certificate-oidc-issuer="https://token.actions.githubusercontent.com" \
  ghcr.io/egohygiene/ubi:0.1.5

docs.title: Issue: Devcontainer fails to build with "base image not found"
docs.text:
Symptoms:

Error response from daemon: manifest for mcr.microsoft.com/devcontainers/base:2.1.2@sha256:... not found

Causes:

  • Base image digest may have been updated or removed upstream
  • Network connectivity issues to Microsoft Container Registry
  • Docker daemon cache issues

Solutions:

  1. Verify base image availability:
docker pull mcr.microsoft.com/devcontainers/base:2.1.2
  1. Check the latest digest:
docker pull mcr.microsoft.com/devcontainers/base:2.1.2
docker inspect mcr.microsoft.com/devcontainers/base:2.1.2 \
  --format='{{index .RepoDigests 0}}'
  1. Update Dockerfile if digest changed:
  2. Update .devcontainer/Dockerfile with new digest

  3. See README.md for full instructions

  4. Clear Docker cache and rebuild:

docker system prune -f
docker build -f .devcontainer/Dockerfile -t ubi:test . --no-cache

docs.title: Issue: "Permission denied" errors during devcontainer build
docs.text:
Symptoms:

mkdir: cannot create directory '/opt/universal/bin': Permission denied

Causes:

  • Incorrect user context in Dockerfile
  • Volume mount permission issues
  • SELinux/AppArmor restrictions

Solutions:

  1. Check Dockerfile USER directive:
# Should run as root during build, then switch to vscode
USER root
RUN mkdir -p /opt/universal/bin
USER vscode
  1. For volume mount issues in docker-compose.yml:
volumes:
  - ..:/workspace:cached  # Add :cached for better performance
  1. On SELinux systems, relabel volumes:
volumes:
  - ..:/workspace:z  # :z for shared, :Z for private

docs.title: Issue: Devcontainer builds but environment is incorrect
docs.text:
Symptoms:

  • Environment variables not set
  • /opt/universal directories missing
  • Wrong locale or timezone

Solutions:

  1. Verify environment in running container:
docker exec -it <container-name> env | grep UNIVERSAL
docker exec -it <container-name> ls -la /opt/universal
  1. Force rebuild without cache:
# In VS Code: Cmd/Ctrl+Shift+P → "Dev Containers: Rebuild Container"
# Or via CLI:
docker-compose -f .devcontainer/docker-compose.yml build --no-cache
  1. Check for overridden environment variables:
  2. Review .devcontainer/devcontainer.json for conflicting remoteEnv
  3. Check .devcontainer/.env file
  4. Verify docker-compose.yml doesn't override ENVs

docs.title: Issue: Builds are slow despite no changes
docs.text:
Symptoms:

  • Every build re-downloads packages
  • Dockerfile changes invalidate all subsequent layers
  • CI builds take excessive time

Solutions:

  1. Optimize Dockerfile layer ordering:
  2. Put rarely-changing steps early (base image, system packages)
  3. Put frequently-changing steps late (application code)

  4. Group related RUN commands to reduce layers

  5. Use Docker BuildKit for better caching:

DOCKER_BUILDKIT=1 docker build -f .devcontainer/Dockerfile -t ubi:local .
  1. Enable BuildKit cache mounts:
RUN --mount=type=cache,target=/var/cache/apt \
    apt-get update && apt-get install -y package-name
  1. In GitHub Actions, use caching:
- name: Set up Docker Buildx
  uses: docker/setup-buildx-action@v3
  with:
    driver-opts: |
      network=host
      image=moby/buildkit:latest

docs.title: Issue: Cache not being used in CI
docs.text:
Symptoms:

  • CI builds from scratch every time
  • Previous layers not reused

Solutions:

  1. Verify GitHub Actions cache configuration:
- name: Build and Push
  uses: docker/build-push-action@v5
  with:
    cache-from: type=gha
    cache-to: type=gha,mode=max
  1. Check layer order in Dockerfile:
  2. Ensure ARG declarations don't unnecessarily invalidate cache
  3. Use multi-stage builds to cache intermediate stages

docs.title: Issue: bump-my-version command fails
docs.text:
Symptoms:

ERROR: Could not find a valid version string
ERROR: No files were modified

Causes:

  • pyproject.toml configuration mismatch
  • VERSION file doesn't match current version in config
  • Regex pattern doesn't match version format

Solutions:

  1. Verify VERSION file content:
cat VERSION
# Should contain only version number (e.g., 0.1.5) with newline
  1. Check pyproject.toml configuration:
grep -A 5 "\[tool.bumpversion\]" pyproject.toml
# Verify current_version matches VERSION file
  1. Manually sync version numbers:
# In pyproject.toml
[tool.poetry]
version = "0.1.5"

[tool.bumpversion]
current_version = "0.1.5"
  1. Test version bump locally:
pip install bump-my-version
bump-my-version patch --dry-run --verbose

docs.title: Issue: Version bump succeeds but tag not created
docs.text:
Symptoms:

  • Commit created with new version
  • Git tag not created
  • CI publish workflow not triggered

Causes:

  • tag = false in pyproject.toml (expected behavior)
  • GitHub Actions workflow not pushing tags
  • Permission issues in workflow

Solutions:

  1. Verify workflow configuration in bump-version.yml:
- name: Push bump commit + tags
  uses: ad-m/github-push-action@master
  with:
    github_token: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
    branch: main
    tags: true  # Ensure this is set
  1. Check workflow permissions:
permissions:
  contents: write  # Required for tag creation
  1. Manually create tag if needed:
git tag 0.1.6
git push origin 0.1.6

docs.title: Issue: CHANGELOG.md not being updated
docs.text:
Symptoms:

  • Version bumped but CHANGELOG unchanged
  • CHANGELOG has duplicate entries
  • Wrong format after bump

Causes:

  • pyproject.toml CHANGELOG configuration incorrect
  • Regex pattern not matching CHANGELOG format
  • Manual edits broke the pattern matching

Solutions:

  1. Verify CHANGELOG configuration in pyproject.toml:
[[tool.bumpversion.files]]
filename = "CHANGELOG.md"
regex = true
search = "\\A## "
replace = """## {new_version} ({now:%Y-%m-%d})
[Compare the full difference.](https://github.com/egohygiene/ubi/compare/{current_version}...{new_version})

## """
  1. Check CHANGELOG.md format:
  2. First line after any markdown comments should be ## X.Y.Z (YYYY-MM-DD)

  3. Pattern must match exactly

  4. Fix broken CHANGELOG:

# Ensure first version header starts at beginning of line
# Example correct format:
## {new_version} ({now:%Y-%m-%d})
[Compare the full difference.](https://github.com/egohygiene/ubi/compare/{current_version}...{new_version})
  1. Test CHANGELOG update:
bump-my-version patch --dry-run --verbose
# Check output for CHANGELOG modifications

docs.title: Issue: CHANGELOG has merge conflicts
docs.text:
Symptoms:

  • Git merge conflicts in CHANGELOG.md
  • Multiple version entries colliding

Solutions:

  1. Resolve manually prioritizing chronological order:
## 0.1.6 (2025-12-13)
[Compare...]

## 0.1.5 (2025-12-11)
[Compare...]
  1. Keep newest version at top:
  2. Remove conflict markers
  3. Ensure versions are in descending order
  4. Preserve all unique entries

docs.title: Issue: XDG directories not being used by applications
docs.text:
Symptoms:

  • Applications still write to ~/.config
  • Cache files in home directory
  • XDG_* variables set but ignored

Causes:

  • Application doesn't support XDG
  • Variables set but directories don't exist
  • Permission issues on XDG directories

Solutions:

  1. Verify directories exist and are writable:
ls -la /opt/universal/
touch /opt/universal/config/test && rm /opt/universal/config/test
  1. Check if application supports XDG:
# Some apps need explicit configuration
# Example for pip:
mkdir -p $XDG_CONFIG_HOME/pip
echo "[global]" > $XDG_CONFIG_HOME/pip/pip.conf
  1. Set application-specific overrides:
# Example for npm
export NPM_CONFIG_USERCONFIG=$XDG_CONFIG_HOME/npm/npmrc

docs.title: Issue: Cannot pull UBI image from GHCR
docs.text:
Symptoms:

Error response from daemon: unauthorized: authentication required
Error: ghcr.io/egohygiene/ubi:0.1.5 not found

Solutions:

  1. Authenticate to GitHub Container Registry:
echo $GITHUB_TOKEN | docker login ghcr.io -u USERNAME --password-stdin
  1. Verify image exists:
curl -s "https://ghcr.io/v2/egohygiene/ubi/tags/list" | jq
  1. Try with explicit tag:
docker pull ghcr.io/egohygiene/ubi:latest
docker pull ghcr.io/egohygiene/ubi:0.1.5
  1. Check package visibility:
  2. Visit https://github.com/orgs/egohygiene/packages
  3. Ensure package is public or you have access

docs.title: Issue: Cannot write to /opt/universal directories
docs.text:
Symptoms:

touch: cannot touch '/opt/universal/cache/test': Permission denied

Solutions:

  1. Check directory ownership:
ls -la /opt/universal/
# Should be owned by vscode:vscode
  1. Fix permissions:
# In Dockerfile:
RUN chown -R vscode:vscode /opt/universal
  1. Verify current user:
whoami  # Should be 'vscode'
id      # Check groups

docs.title: Privileged Mode in Devcontainer - Security Analysis
Executive Summary
docs.text: Status: ✅ REMOVED - privileged: true was not necessary Date Investigated: 2025-12-12 Priority: P2 (Medium) Decision: Removed from .devcontainer/docker-compose.yml

docs.title: Background
docs.text:
The UBI devcontainer configuration previously included privileged: true in the docker-compose.yml file with a comment indicating it was "required for docker-in-docker". This setting significantly escalates container privileges and breaks isolation boundaries, presenting potential security risks.

This document explains the investigation, findings, and final decision regarding this configuration.

docs.title: Original Configuration
docs.text:
The .devcontainer/docker-compose.yml file contained:

services:
  development:
    # ... other settings ...
    privileged: true # required for docker-in-docker
    user: vscode

docs.title: What is Privileged Mode?
docs.text:
When a container runs in privileged mode (privileged: true):

  • Full device access: The container gains access to all host devices (/dev/*)
  • Kernel capabilities: Nearly all Linux capabilities are granted
  • No AppArmor/SELinux restrictions: Security profiles are disabled
  • Control groups relaxed: Resource isolation is weakened
  • Host namespace access: Can potentially access host processes and filesystems

This effectively removes the security boundaries that containers are designed to provide.

docs.title: Security Risks of Privileged Mode
docs.text:
1. Host Filesystem Access: Container can potentially access and modify host files
  2. Kernel Interface Exposure: Direct access to kernel interfaces increases attack surface
  3. Container Escape: Easier to escape container isolation and compromise the host
  4. Privilege Escalation: Simplified path to gaining root access on the host
  5. Non-portable Configuration: Makes the devcontainer less portable across environments

docs.title: 1. No Docker-in-Docker Requirement
docs.text:
Analysis of the codebase revealed:

  • ✅ The Dockerfile (.devcontainer/Dockerfile) does NOT install Docker CLI or Docker Engine
  • ✅ No Docker daemon is configured to run inside the container
  • ✅ No docker.sock mounting is configured in the devcontainer
  • ✅ CI/CD workflows (GitHub Actions) run Docker commands on the host runner, not inside the devcontainer
  • ✅ The base image (mcr.microsoft.com/devcontainers/base) does not include Docker by default

Conclusion: There is no Docker-in-Docker (DinD) usage in this project.

docs.title: 2. CI/CD Architecture
docs.text:
The GitHub Actions workflows (.github/workflows/publish.yml, .github/workflows/test-image.yml) build and test the UBI image using:

  • Docker Buildx on the GitHub Actions runner (host)
  • Standard Docker build commands
  • No requirement for nested containerization

The devcontainer is only used for local development in VS Code, not for building or testing the image.

docs.title: 3. Local Development Requirements
docs.text:
Investigated whether privileged mode is needed for:

  • ❌ Docker-in-Docker: Not used
  • ❌ Low-level host operations: Not required
  • ❌ Special device access: Not needed
  • ❌ Kernel module loading: Not required
  • ❌ Network configuration: Standard networking is sufficient
  • ❌ Mount operations: Standard bind mounts work without privileged mode

Conclusion: No legitimate use case exists for privileged mode in this devcontainer.

docs.title: Alternatives Evaluated
docs.text: Even if Docker-in-Docker were required, safer alternatives exist:

docs.title: 1. Docker Socket Binding (Recommended)
docs.text:
Instead of running Docker inside Docker, bind the host's Docker socket:

services:
  development:
    volumes:
      - /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock

Pros:

  • No privileged mode required
  • Uses host Docker daemon
  • Better performance
  • Simpler configuration

Cons:

  • Still requires careful permission management
  • Grants significant access to host Docker daemon

docs.title: 2. Rootless Docker
docs.text:
Run Docker daemon without root privileges:

services:
  development:
    environment:
      - DOCKER_HOST=unix:///run/user/1000/docker.sock

Pros:

  • Enhanced security
  • No root privileges required
  • Better isolation

Cons:

  • More complex setup
  • Some features may be limited

docs.title: 3. Specific Capabilities
docs.text:
Grant only required Linux capabilities instead of full privileged mode:

services:
  development:
    cap_add:
      - SYS_ADMIN
      - NET_ADMIN

Pros:

  • Principle of least privilege
  • Better than full privileged mode
  • Fine-grained control

Cons:

  • Requires careful analysis of needed capabilities
  • Still presents some security risks

docs.title: Rationale
docs.text:
1. No functional requirement: Docker-in-Docker is not used anywhere in the project
  2. Security improvement: Removing privileged mode significantly enhances container security
  3. Alignment with best practices: Follows principle of least privilege
  4. No impact on functionality: All existing workflows and local development scenarios work without it
  5. Better isolation: Maintains proper container isolation boundaries

docs.title: Implementation
docs.text:
The change is minimal and surgical:

File: .devcontainer/docker-compose.yml

services:
  development:
    container_name: ${PROJECT_NAME:-profile}-development
    hostname: ${PROJECT_NAME:-profile}-development
    build:
      context: ..
      target: final
      dockerfile: .devcontainer/Dockerfile
    volumes:
      - ..:/workspace:cached
    command: sleep infinity
-   privileged: true # required for docker-in-docker
    user: vscode
    <<: *settings

docs.title: Tests Performed
docs.text:
1. ✅ Devcontainer Rebuild: Container builds successfully without privileged mode
  2. ✅ Environment Variables: All environment variables are correctly set
  3. ✅ XDG Directories: All /opt/universal/* directories are accessible
  4. ✅ File Permissions: User vscode has correct permissions
  5. ✅ CI Workflows: All GitHub Actions workflows continue to operate normally
  6. ✅ Local Development: VS Code devcontainer attaches and functions correctly

docs.title: Validation Commands
docs.text:
# Build and start the devcontainer
docker-compose -f .devcontainer/docker-compose.yml up -d

# Verify directory structure
docker exec profile-development ls -la /opt/universal

# Verify environment variables
docker exec profile-development env | grep UNIVERSAL

# Test vscode user permissions
docker exec -u vscode profile-development touch /opt/universal/cache/test

All tests passed without privileged mode.

docs.title: Security Improvements
docs.text: By removing privileged: true, the following security improvements are achieved:

docs.title: Before (with privileged mode)
docs.text:
• ❌ Container could access all host devices
  • ❌ Full kernel capability access
  • ❌ No AppArmor/SELinux enforcement
  • ❌ Potential container escape vectors
  • ❌ Host compromise risk

docs.title: After (without privileged mode)
docs.text:
• ✅ Standard container isolation maintained
  • ✅ Limited kernel capabilities (only required ones)
  • ✅ AppArmor/SELinux profiles enforced
  • ✅ Reduced attack surface
  • ✅ Better compliance with security standards
  • ✅ Defense in depth maintained

docs.title: If Docker Access is Needed in the Future
docs.text:
Should the need arise to run Docker commands from within the devcontainer:

  1. First Choice: Bind mount Docker socket (see "Alternatives Evaluated" above)
  2. Second Choice: Install Docker CLI only and use host daemon via socket
  3. Last Resort: Use Docker-in-Docker feature with rootless mode
  4. Never: Do not re-enable privileged: true without thorough justification and security review

docs.title: Documentation Requirements
docs.text:
Any future changes that require elevated privileges must:

  • Be documented in this file with clear justification
  • Include specific risks and mitigations
  • Be reviewed by security team
  • Consider principle of least privilege
  • Evaluate all alternatives first

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text:
The investigation conclusively determined that privileged: true was not necessary for any functionality in the UBI devcontainer. The flag has been safely removed, resulting in improved security posture while maintaining full functionality.

Key Takeaways:

  • Always question the necessity of privileged mode
  • Investigate alternatives before granting elevated privileges
  • Document security decisions thoroughly
  • Test changes to validate no functionality is lost
  • Follow principle of least privilege
